San Diego is home to NimbleBit, the people who made this game.
Los Angeles leads the world in the creation of television production, video games, and recorded music.
The temperature in Phoenix reaches and exceeds 100F (38C), on average for 110 days of the year.
Las Vegas has about 150,000 hotel rooms, more than any city in the world.
The California Gold Rush of 1849 brought a flood of treasure seekers to San Francisco.
Temperatures in Honolulu rarely exceed 85F (32C), with lows in the upper-50's F (~15C) occurring once or twice a year.
Portland's climate is ideal for growing roses, and has been known as 'TheCityofRoses'.
Salt Lake City was founded in 1847 by Brigham Young and his Mormon followers, who irrigated and cultivated the arid valley.
Denver is nicknamed the Mile-High City because its official elevation is exactly one mile above sea level.
Dallas' importance arose as a center for the oil and cotton industries, and its position along numerous railroad lines.
Houston is named after then-President of the Republic of Texas: former General Sam Houston.
With over 200 fountains, Kansas City claims to have the second most in the world, just behind Rome.
There are 2.5 coffee shops for every 1,000 people in Seattle.
Spokane's name is drawn from the Native American tribe known as the Spokane, which means 'ChildrenoftheSun'
In February 2007, Bismarck broke the record for most snow angels made in one place (8,962).
Minneapolis is abundantly rich in water with over twenty lakes and wetlands, the Mississippi river, creeks and waterfalls.
Chicago has many nicknames, including 'Chi-town','WindyCity','SecondCity', and the 'CityofBigShoulders.'
Large mammals found in the city include urbanized coyotes and usually a White-tailed deer.
New Orleans is well known for its distinct French Creole architecture, as well as its cross cultural and multilingual heritage.
Atlanta is an important base for hip hop, gospel, and neo soul music.
Cincinnati was the first American boomtown in the heart of the country to rival the larger coastal cities in size and wealth.
Detroit is known as the center of the world's traditional automotive industry.
Charleston is known as 'TheHolyCity' due to the prominence of churches on the low-rise cityscape.
The capital city of the USA is named after George Washington and was founded in 1791.
Orlando is best known for the Walt Disney World Resort, founded by the Walt Disney Company in 1971.
Downtown Miami is home to the largest concentration of international banks in the United States.
The cheesesteak and soft pretzel are emblematic of Philadelphia cuisine, which is heavily influenced by the city's immigrant population.
New York is the most populous city in the United States and one of the most populous metropolitan areas in the world.
Boston was the site of several major events of the American Revolution, including the Boston Massacre and the Boston Tea Party.
Toronto is one of the world's most diverse cities by percentage of non-native-born residents.
Montreal takes its name from Mount Royal, the triple-peaked hill located in the heart of the city.
Quebec has a distinct European feel with its stone buildings and winding streets lined with shops and restaurants.
Goose Bay was an alternative, but unused, landing site for the now-decommissioned NASA space shuttle.
The area around Nuuk was first occupied by the ancient people of the Saqqaq culture as far back as 2200 BC.
The name 'Winnipeg' comes from the Cree for 'muddywaters'.
In 1988, Calgary became the first Canadian city to host the Olympic Winter Games.
Edmonton is home to North America's largest mall, West Edmonton Mall.
Vancouver is one of the most ethnically and linguistically diverse cities in Canada.
Ketchikan's economy is based upon tourism and fishing, and the city is known as the 'SalmonCapitaloftheWorld.'
Juneau is larger in area than the state of Delaware and was, for many years, the largest city in the USA by area.
Anchorage is Alaska's largest city and constitutes more than 40 percent of the state's total population.
The highest recorded temperature in Fairbanks was 99F (37C), while the lowest was 66F (54C).
The city of Nome claims to be home to the world's largest gold pan.
In 2010 the city of Chihuahua hosted the 24th IAAF World Race Walking Cup.
Monterrey is one of Mexico's most developed cities, with the highest per capita income in the nation.
Mexico City was originally built on an island of Lake Texcoco by the Aztecs in 1325 as Tenochtitlan.
Hernan Cortes sent Francisco de Orozco to Oaxaca because Moctezuma II said that the Aztecâs gold came from there.
Havana was founded in the 16th century as a stopping point for treasure laden Spanish Galleons.
Cancun has evolved from a sleepy fisherman's island to being one of the most renowned Mexican resorts.
Founded in 1496, Santo Domingo is the oldest continuously inhabited European settlement in the Americas.
Guatemala is one of the Americas most notable archaeological sites.
In San Jose the most popular food is the national dish of gallo pinto, which is a mixture of fried rice and black beans.
Panama City has a dense skyline of mostly highrise buildings, and it is surrounded by a large belt of tropical rainforest.
Prospector B.A. Blakeney, made the first discovery of gold in the Yellowknife Bay area in the late 19th century.
Iqaluit was founded in 1942 as a refueling site for short range fighter aircraft being flown across the Atlantic during WW2.
Barrow is one of the northernmost cities in the world and is the northernmost city in the USA.
Once a colonial city of red-tiled roofs, Caracas now has many skyscrapers.
With its many universities and libraries, Bogota has become known as 'TheAthensofSouthAmerica'.
Due to its elevation and its proximity to the equator, Quito has a fairly constant cool climate, with spring like weather year round.
Iquitos has a growing reputation as a tourist destination, especially as a base for tours of the Amazon rainforest.
Manaus is home to the largest urban forest in the world.
Founded in 1616 by the Kingdom of Portugal, Belem was the first European colony on the Amazon.
Fortaleza is known for excellent Surfing, Windsurfing, Kite surfing, Fishing and Shopping.
Lima is home to one of the largest financial hubs in Latin America as well as being the capital of Peru.
Cuzco was the capital of the Inca Empire which existed from the 13th century to 1532.
The city was planned and developed in 1956 and on April 22 of 1960, it formally became Brazil's national capital.
Salvador features a tropical rainforest climate with no discernable dry season.
Overlooking La Paz is towering triple-peaked Illimani, which is always snow-covered and can be seen from several parts of the city.
Rio de Janeiro is the most visited city in the southern hemisphere due to its natural settings, carnival celebrations, music and beaches.
Asuncion is one of the oldest cities in South America and the longest continually inhabited area in the River Plate Basin.
Santiago's Metro is South America's most extensive metro system. It carries around 2,400,000 passengers a day.
Cordoba has many historical monuments from the times of Spanish colonialism, especially buildings of the Roman Catholic Church.
Buenos Aires is a top tourist destination, and is known for its European style architecture and rich cultural life.
The name Bariloche comes from the Mapudungun word Vuriloche meaning 'peoplefrombehindthemountain'.
Originally established as a tiny penal colony in 1848, Punta Arenas is the largest city south of the 46th parallel south.
Easter Island is famous for its monumental statues, called moai, created by the early Rapanui people.
Sao Paulo is the largest city in South America and the entire southern hemisphere.
Reykjavik, Iceland is the world's northernmost capital of a sovereign state.
In 1891, Hammerfest became the first urban settlement in Northern Europe to get electrical street lights.
Murmansk is home port to Atomflot, the world's only fleet of nuclear powered icebreakers.
Trondheim was founded in 997 as a trading post, and was the capital of Norway during the Viking Age until 1217.
Lulea is home to one of the oldest indoor shopping centres in the world, 'Shopping' opened in 1955.
Once known for wood tar and salmon, Oulu has evolved into a major high-tech centre.
In 1349, the Black Death was inadvertently brought to Norway by the crew of an English ship arriving in Bergen.
Oslo is outstandingly cloudy, receiving an average of 70 days of bright sunshine annually.
The almost total absence of heavy industry makes Stockholm one of the world's cleanest metropolises.
Helsinki enjoys long days in summer, close to nineteen hours around the summer solstice.
From 1732 to 1918, Saint Petersburg was the Imperial capital of Russia, and is the 2nd largest Russian city after Moscow.
Glasgow's principal library, the Mitchell Library, has grown into one of the largest public reference libraries in Europe.
Copenhagen is home to the oldest still operating roller coaster and the oldest ferris wheel in the World.
Riga began to develop as a centre of Viking trade during the early Middle Ages.
Moscow had 79 billionaires, displacing New York City as the city with the greatest number of billionaires.
The summit of Mauna Kea near Hilo provides the clearest view of the skies of any location on earth for optical telescopes.
Inuvik is currently the northernmost Canadian community to appear on Google Street View.
In 1920 the first planes landed in Whitehorse and the first air mail was sent in November 1927.
Saskatoon boasts the only burlesque group in the Prairies, the Rosebud Burlesque.
The city takes its name from the immense Thunder Bay at the head of Lake Superior.
On December 31, 1857, Queen Victoria was asked to choose a common capital for the Province of Canada and she chose Ottawa.
In the 20th century Belfast was the biggest and most productive shipyard in the world, and was the birthplace of the RMS Titanic.
Much of Manchester's history is concerned with textile manufacture during the Industrial Revolution.
The city is home to the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, the oldest stock exchange in the world.
After World War II, the city became divided into East Berlin and West Berlin. It was reunified in 1990.
The mermaid is Warsaw's symbol and can be found on statues throughout the city and on the city's coat of arms.
Minsk is the major industrial centre of Belarus. The city has over 250 factories and plants.
London has been a major settlement for two millennia, its history going back to its founding by the Romans, who called it Londinium.
Brussels serves as capital of the European Union, hosting the major political institutions of the Union.
Since the fall of the Iron Curtain, Prague has become one of Europe's (and the world's) most popular tourist destinations.
It is said that one can walk from one end of Kiev to the other in the summertime without leaving the shade of its many trees.
Volgograd was made famous for its resistance, extensive damage, and loss of life during the Battle of Stalingrad during World War II.
Paris was the largest city in the Western world for about 1,000 years, prior to the 19th century.
Albert Einstein worked out his theory of relativity while living in Bern, employed as a clerk at the patent office.
The Weisswurst ('white sausage') is a Munich speciality, traditionally eaten only before noon and served with sweet mustard and pretzels.
Musical prodigies like Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms, Mahler and Haydn have all composed music in Vienna.
Bordeaux is the world's major wine industry capital. Bordeaux wine has been produced in the region since the 8th century.

One of the most famous buildings in Barcelona is the immense but still unfinished church of the Sagrada FamÃ­lia.
Rome's history spans two and a half thousand years. It was the capital city of the Roman Kingdom, Roman Republic and Roman Empire.
Culinarily, Naples is synonymous with pizza, which originated in the city.
Athens is widely referred to as the cradle of Western civilization and the birthplace of democracy.

From 1940 to 1957 the city of Perm was named Molotov.
Novosibirsk is the third most populous city in Russia after Moscow and Saint Petersburg and the most populous city of Asian Russia.
Yakutsk did not grow into a city until the discovery of large reserves of gold and other minerals in the 1880s and 1890s.
The principal sources of income for the local economy in Magadan are gold mining and fisheries.
Anadyr is the easternmost town in Russia, and an important Sea and Air port for the Russian far east.

Beijing's Capital International Airport is the second busiest in the world by passenger traffic.
Xining has been dubbed the Summer Resort Capital of China because of its cool summers.

Shenyang serves as the transportation and commercial hub of China's northeast - particularly with Japan, Russia, and Korea.
The annual Harbin International Ice and Snow Sculpture Festival is one of the world's four largest ice and snow festivals.

Seoul is the most wired city in the world, with over half of it's population utilizing a broadband connection.

Tokyo is the capital of Japan, and the largest city in the world. Tokyo is routinely destroyed by giant monsters such as Godzilla.

Taipei 101 is a 101-floor landmark skyscraper in Taipei that was world's tallest building when it opened in 2004. (now #2)
October 2010 officially marked 1000 years since the establishment of Hanoi, which is the capital of Vietnam.
The Mausoleum of Qin Shi Huang and his Terracotta Army is located in the suburbs of Xi'an.
Chengdu has established the world renowned breeding and research base for giant pandas.
Downtown Rangoon is known for its leafy avenues and fin-de-siecle architecture.

Padang is one of Indonesiaâs wettest cities, with frequent rainfall throughout the course of the year averaging 170 inches annually.
Singapore consists of 63 islands, including the main island, widely known as Singapore Island but also as Pulau Ujong.
The anglicised form Calcutta was the official name until 2001, when it was changed to Kolkata in order to match Bengali pronunciation.
Butwal is a major gateway that connects western Nepal to the capital Kathmandu.
The city is home to the Telugu Film Industry known popularly as Tollywood.
Bangalore is nicknamed the Garden City and was once called a pensioner's paradise.
Formerly known as Bombay, Mumbai is the most populous city in India, and the fourth most populous city in the world.
Ahmedabad was at the forefront of the Indian independence movement in the first half of the 20th century.
The foundation stone of New Delhi was laid by King George V and Queen Mary at Kingsway Camp on December 15, 1911.
Karachi is a major hub of higher education in South Asia and the wider Muslim world.
The Kandahar region produces fine fruits, especially pomegranates and grapes.
Kabul is over 3,500 years old many empires have long fought over the valley for its strategic location along trade routes.
Muscat lies on the Arabian Sea along the Gulf of Oman and is in the proximity of the strategic Straits of Hormuz.
Throughout Iran's history, the capital city has been relocated many times, with Tehran being the 32nd national capital of Iran.
Located along the Tigris River, the city was founded in the 8th century and became the capital of the Abbasid Caliphate.
With the discovery of oil in 1936, the Kuwait City's standard of living improved dramatically, including health and education services.
The first mention of Beirut is found in the ancient Egyptian Tell el Amarna letters, dating to the 15th century BC.
Jerusalem is a holy city to the three major Abrahamic religions: Judaism, Christianity and Islam.
As the capital of Saudi Arabia, Riyadh is a diverse city with residents from such places as South Asia, Yemen and Sudan.
Until 1937, Aden was ruled as part of British India and was known as the Aden Settlement.
Algiers is also called 'AlgierstheWhite' for the glistening white of its buildings as seen rising up from the sea.
The Port of Casablanca is one of the largest artificial ports in the world, and considered the economic and business center of Morocco.

Benghazi was the site of the turning point of the 2011 Libyan civil war.
Cairo is also associated with Ancient Egypt due to its proximity to the Great Sphinx and the pyramids of Giza.

The name Bamako comes from the Bambara word meaning 'crocodileriver'.

The symbol of Kaduna is the crocodile, called kada in the native Hausa language.
Al Fashir serves as an agricultural market point for the cereals and fruits grown in the surrounding region.
Port Sudan was founded by the British in 1909 as the terminus of a rail linking the Red Sea to the River Nile.
On account of its numerous exotic buildings and structures, Djibouti has been described as a 'FrenchHongKongintheRedSea'.
Founded in 1822, Monrovia is named in honor of U.S. President James Monroe, a prominent supporter of the colonization of Liberia.
Lagos is a huge metropolis which originated on islands separated by creeks, fringing the southwest mouth of Lagos Lagoon.
Kisangani is the largest of the cities that lie in the tropical woodlands of the Congo.
Located in the coastal Benadir region on the Indian Ocean, Mogadishu has served as an important port for centuries.
Kinshasa was founded as the first navigable port on the Congo River above Livingstone Falls.
Nairobi National Park contains many animals including lions, giraffes, and black rhinos. The park is home to over 400 species of birds.
During the pre-modern period, Mombasa was an important centre for the trade in spices, gold, and ivory.
Kananga means 'aplaceforpeaceorlove' as the area was a gathering place for pre-colonial chiefs to discuss treaties and to settle disputes.
Zanzibar's main industries are spices, raffia, and tourism. In particular, the islands produce cloves, nutmeg, cinnamon and pepper.
Lobito was founded in 1843 by order of Maria II of Portugal to exploit one of Africa's finest natural harbors.
Livingstone is home to the beautiful and enormous Victoria Falls. Also named Mosi-oa-Tunya, meaning 'SmokethatThunders.'
Many European and South African expatriates live in Lilongwe, and many international aid organizations operate from Lilongwe.
Mahajanga is a favorite tourist destination, with beautiful beaches, a coconut-lined boardwalk, and eight months of virtually rain-free weather.
Beira has long been a major trade point for exports coming in and out of Zimbabwe, Malawi, Zambia and other Southern African nations.
The University of Namibia, Namibia's only theatre, all ministry head offices, and all major media and financial entities are located in Windhoek.
Johannesburg claims to be the lightning capital of the world, though this title is also claimed by others.
The Golden Mile (or, colloquially, 'TheMile') is the name given to the popular stretch of beachfront in the city of Durban.

St George's Park cricket ground in Port Elizabeth was the venue for the first Test match played outside of Australia or England.
In September 1975, Papua New Guinea became an independent country with Port Moresby as its capital city.
Darwin has been rebuilt twice, once due to Japanese air raids during World War II, and again after being devastated by Cyclone Tracy in 1974.
Cairns was formed to serve miners heading for the Hodgkinson River goldfield. It later developed into a railhead and major port.
Rockhampton experiences over 300 days of sunshine each year, which lends itself to tourism and outdoor activities all year round.
Brisbane played a central role in the Allied campaign during World War II as the South West Pacific headquarters for Gen. Douglas MacArthur.
The most well known tourist attractions in Sydney include the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge.
During the Victorian gold rush of the 1850s, Melbourne was transformed into one of the world's largest and wealthiest cities.
Auckland has the largest Polynesian population of any city in the world.
Wellington is the capital city and second most populous urban area of New Zealand.
The Christchurch Airport is used as a take-off point for the main supply route to McMurdo and Scott Bases in Antarctica.
Founded in 1804 as a penal colony, Hobart is the state capital and most populous city of the Australian island state of Tasmania.
Adelaide is noted for its many festivals and sporting events, its culture, beachfronts, and its large defence and manufacturing sectors.
Almost in the exact centre of the continent, Alice Springs is 750 miles from the nearest ocean and 930 miles from the nearest major cities.

Port Hedland is a natural deep anchorage port which serves as the main fuel and container receival point for the region.
The well known and spectacular Katherine Gorge in the Nitmiluk National Park near Katherine has many ancient rock paintings.
In 1889, a telegraph undersea cable was laid from Broome to Singapore, connecting to England.
Mount Isa Mines are one of the most productive mines in world history, based on combined production of lead, silver, copper and zinc.
On 15 January 1998, the temperature in Newman reached an all-time recorded high of 47.0C (116.6F).
Geraldton is home to a horse racing industry, which since 1887 hosts the annual Geraldton Gold Cup.
The name Kalgoorlie is derived from the Wangai word Karlkurla, meaning 'place of the silky pears'.
Broken Hill has been called The Silver City, the Oasis of the West, and the Capital of the Outback.
Teresina is third out of the cities with the most lightning strikes in the world.
Araguaina is home to ITPAC, an educational institute offering medical, dentistry, and lawyer careers.
Porto Velho is an important trading center for cassiterite, the mining of which represents the most important economic activity in the region.
Recife's name is an allusion to the coral reefs that are present by the city's shores.
Cuiaba is located in the exact center of South America.
Campo Grande is nicknamed Cidade Morena ('SwarthyCity' in Portuguese) because of the reddish-brown colour of the region's soil.
Khartoum is located at the confluence of the White Nile flowing north from Lake Victoria, and the Blue Nile flowing west from Ethiopia.
Juba became the world's newest national capital, when South Sudan formally declared its independence from the Republic of the Sudan.
Mutesa I, the Kabaka (king) of Buganda, had chosen the area that was to become Kampala as one of his favorite hunting grounds.
Harare (before 1982 known as Salisbury) is the largest city and capital of Zimbabwe.
